head.title: To Save Power, the Old-Fashioned Way

hedline.hl1: To Save Power, the Old-Fashioned Way

abstract.p: Thomas Pearson letter on July 17 article calls for complete privatization of electric utility industry; drawing

block.p: You report that some electric utility companies are saving money and conserving energy by giving consumers financial incentives to curtail use, especially during peak hours (front page, July 17).

Of course these only seem like novel ideas to the electric companies because of their decades of history as government-managed monopolies. Now that new technologies and attempts at deregulation are giving utilities a glimpse of free-market conditions, the companies are beginning to act like market competitors concerned with the needs of their customers.
You report that some electric utility companies are saving money and conserving energy by giving consumers financial incentives to curtail use, especially during peak hours (front page, July 17).

Of course these only seem like novel ideas to the electric companies because of their decades of history as government-managed monopolies. Now that new technologies and attempts at deregulation are giving utilities a glimpse of free-market conditions, the companies are beginning to act like market competitors concerned with the needs of their customers.
As a result, prices are dropping and service is improving.
Complete privatization would further these trends and eliminate the need for government subsidies altogether.
The writer is a research assistant, Competitive Enterprise Institute.
